contentheadline.headline: Ode for the Birthday of Queen Anne

contentrichtext.text: {{Handel}} '''''Ode for the Birthday of Queen Anne''''' ([[HWV]] 74) is a [[Cantata|secular cantata]] composed by [[George Frideric Handel]] to a [[libretto]] by [[Ambrose Philips]], of which the first line, "'''Eternal source of light divine'''", provides an alternative title for the work. It was probably composed during January 1713 for a performance on 6 February 1713 (which did not occur).<ref name="Grove2001Vol10Page784">{{NewGrove2001|Handel, George Frideric|Anthony Hicks|x|784}}</ref> Other catalogues of Handel's music have referred to the work as [[Händel-Gesellschaft|HG]] xlviA; and [[Hallische Händel-Ausgabe|HHA]] i/6.<ref name="Grove2001Vol10Page784" /> ==Overview== The cantata celebrates [[Queen Anne of England|Queen Anne's]] birthday, and the accomplishment of the [[Treaty of Utrecht]] (negotiated by the [[Tory]] ministry of Anne in 1712) to end the [[War of the Spanish Succession]]. == Structure == Each of the seven stanzas of the ode concludes with the following words sung by the chorus: : ''The day that gave great Anna birth'', : ''Who fix'd a lasting peace on Earth''. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMSLP2|id=Ode for the Birthday of Queen Anne, HWV 74 (Handel, George Frideric)|cname=Ode for the Birthday of Queen Anne}} {{George Frideric Handel}} [[Category:Cantatas by George Frideric Handel]] [[Category:Anne, Queen of Great Britain]] [[Category:1713 compositions]]
